author: Ryan Breeden rbreeden@stwnewspress.com
title: Meet the new Cowboys: Breaking down Oklahoma State’s notable signees in the 2025 class | Sports | stwnewspress.com
text:
Oklahoma State’s early signing day went mostly according to plan, and 19 future Cowboys signed their letters of intent Wednesday morning.
The one hiccup came from former three-star quarterback commit Jett Niu, who flipped his commitment Bedlam style early Wednesday morning by signing with the Sooners. On the flip side of the flips, OSU picked up a commitment from Muskogee offensive lineman Miguel Chaves – previously committed to UNLV before late Tuesday night.
Of the 19 players signed, 11 are on offense and eight are on defense with three guys coming from JUCO. Nine of the 19 are expected to be on campus next month as early enrollees.
Chandavian Bradley, edge rusher, 6-foot-4, 242 pounds - Hutchinson C.C.
Bradley might be OSU’s best pickup in the entire signing class. He comes to Stillwater from Hutchinson Community College in Kansas, where he’s the No. 1 ranked JUCO edge rusher in the class and the No. 13 overall JUCO prospect.
Prior to his one season at Hutchinson, Bradley was the No. 84 overall prospect out of high school and committed to Tennessee over Texas A&M, South Carolina, LSU and many other power four programs.
This season, he was named an all-conference honorable mention in the KJCCC, and he recorded 23 tackles with 6.0 tackles for loss as a redshirt freshman. He has three years of eligibility left and will be an early enrollee. Oklahoma State has plenty of need for defensive line help with the departure of Colin Oliver, and Bradley could see the field early on in replacement.
Rashod Bradley, defensive end, 6-foot-3, 255 pounds - East Mississippi C.C.
Another defensive lineman from JUCO with the last name Bradley joined the class leading up to signing day.
Bradley picked OSU over Arkansas, South Florida, North Texas and others, and with his frame and experience he could factor in on the defensive line early on, like the other Bradley.
In two seasons at East Mississippi C.C., he combined for 32 tackles and 6.0 tackles for loss. Bradley has two years of eligibility left and will be on campus this spring.
Draden Fullbright, cornerback, 5-foot-11, 175 pounds - North Crowley, Texas
Fullbright flipped to Oklahoma State from Tulsa just two days before signing day. He will enter a DB room that is set to lose Korie Black, Trey Rucker, Lyrik Rawls, Willie Nelson and others.
Prior to his time at North Crowley, where he has helped lead it to the state regional finals this year, Fullbright played in Wayne County, Georgia, contributing at defensive back and running back. In 2024, he was listed as a Fort Worth Star-Telegram top-100 area player.
Fullbright is a three-star recruit who had an impressive offer sheet – including offers from Georgia, USC, Florida State and others. He will not be an early enrollee.
Royal Cappel, wide receiver, 5-foot-11, 175 - Cibolo (Steele), Texas
It will be interesting to see how this shakes out after the firing of OC/WR coach Kasey Dunn, but should Cappel stick around in Stillwater, he has plenty of upside.
Cappel’s frame and track speed (ran a 10.99 in the 100m last year) projects him as a slot receiver – where he produced for Cibolo in his senior year. Cappel racked up 1,200 yards and 13 receiving touchdowns, and he also averaged more than 30 yards per return on special teams.
He is a three-star recruit and picked OSU over Baylor, Missouri, Oklahoma and plenty others. Cappel is another early enrollee.
Chase Pinkston, defensive back, 6-feet, 195 pounds - Jones C.C.
Pinkston was a signing day commit and signee for the Pokes. He played one season at Jones, where he recorded 26 tackles, three interceptions and a fumble recovery as a true freshman.
He was a three-star prospect out of Oak Grove High School in Mississippi and had interest from OSU but no official offer. After his one season at a JUCO, Pinkston was re-evaluated by the Cowboys and they offered.
It’s worth noting that Pinkston’s father, Todd, is the running backs coach for the Kansas City Chiefs.
Michael Riles, edge rusher, 6-foot-4, 245 pounds - Port Arthur, Texas
Riles is the second-highest rated recruit in OSU’s signing class.
With his size and speed around the edge, schools such as Texas A&M, Florida, Texas and others all offered – but he stuck with Oklahoma State.
Riles is the No. 52 rated player in Texas and will arrive on campus in the fall.
Carl’Veon Young, linebacker, 6-foot-4, 215 pounds - Midwest City, Oklahoma
Oklahoma State’s highest rated recruit is an in-state recruit from Carl Albert.
Young has shot up the recruiting rankings in the last month, going from the No. 407 nationally ranked player to No. 219 as of signing day. In October, Young was an unrated recruit, and now he is a four-star.
At linebacker, Young describes himself as a versatile player that can be a factor in stopping the run and dropping back in coverage on pass plays. Young is looking to win a third straight state championship at Carl Albert, and he has more than 60 tackles with two sacks and an interception this season.
Young is the latest example of Oklahoma State finding a hidden gem before the rest of the country finds him. OSU was his only offer even on signing day – and as a four star recruit that’s almost unheard of.
DJ Dugar, running back, 6-foot-1, 205 pounds - Leander, Texas
Dugar brings an interesting story with him to Oklahoma State.
In three seasons at Tom Glen High School, Dugar carried the ball 533 times for 3,800 yards and 48 touchdowns, but he did not play his senior season. In August, Dugar’s quarterback tore his ACL in a scrimmage. After watching that happen, Dugar took it as a sign to sit out his last year and not risk injury himself after so many carries his first three seasons.
So Dugar will come to Stillwater in January without having taken a carry in more than 12 months. The resumé and the accolades (two-time district player of the year) speak for themselves, but he’ll have to acclimate to competitive reps again. He was a three-star recruit and chose OSU over Arkansas, Kansas State, Missouri and others.

author: Carmen Polk
title: Navigating Sexual Orientation and Identity in College: Support and Resources
text:
College is often a transformative period where students pursue academic excellence and embark on journeys of self-discovery and personal growth. For many individuals, this includes exploring and understanding their sexual orientation and identity. The collegiate environment can be both liberating and challenging, making it crucial to access adequate support and resources to navigate this journey.
Understanding Sexual Orientation & Identity
Sexual orientation and identity encompass a spectrum of experiences and emotions. It involves understanding one’s romantic, emotional, and sexual attractions, which may or may not align with societal norms or expectations. This journey of self-discovery often begins or intensifies during college years as individuals have more autonomy and exposure to diverse perspectives.
The College Experience for LGBTQ+ Students
For LGBTQ+ (Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, Queer/Questioning, and more) students, college can represent a period of exploration and self-acceptance. However, it may also pose challenges, including discrimination, lack of understanding, or feelings of isolation. Creating an inclusive environment where students feel supported and respected is essential.
Supportive Resources on Campus
Colleges and universities increasingly recognize the importance of providing inclusive and supportive resources for LGBTQ+ students. Many institutions offer LGBTQ+ resource centers, student organizations, counseling services, and mentorship programs. These spaces serve as safe havens where students can find community, guidance, and acceptance.
Mentorship & Community Building
Mentorship programs specifically catered to LGBTQ+ students can be immensely beneficial. Connecting with older students, faculty, or staff who identify within the community can provide guidance, support, and a sense of belonging. Additionally, involvement in LGBTQ+ organizations or clubs fosters a sense of community and solidarity.
Counseling & Mental Health Support
Navigating sexual orientation and identity can be emotionally challenging. Colleges often provide counseling services that cater to LGBTQ+ students’ specific needs. Access to therapists who are knowledgeable about LGBTQ+ issues can provide valuable support during periods of self-discovery and self-acceptance.

author: Vinaykumar Patil
title: 'BJP’s Hinduism is fake': Karnataka CM Siddarmaiah draws line between Hindu and Hindutva
text:
'BJP’s Hinduism is fake': Karnataka CM Siddarmaiah draws line between Hindu and Hindutva Karnataka CM Siddaramaiah distinguishes Hinduism from Hindutva, criticizing BJP's 'fake Hinduism.' He champions Congress's contributions to dam construction, digital expansion, and social justice. Endorsing Rahul Gandhi's leadership, he asserts Congress's commitment to secular values against Hindutva's ideology.
Vinaykumar Patil First Published Dec 29, 2023, 1:04 PM IST Follow Karnataka's Chief Minister, Siddaramaiah, articulated a clear distinction between Hinduism and Hindutva while strongly criticizing the BJP's portrayal of what he termed 'fake Hinduism.' Addressing the Congress Foundation Day celebrations at the KPCC office, Siddaramaiah highlighted the contrast between the two ideologies.
During the event, Siddaramaiah emphasized that his recent attendance at a bhajan during Dhanurmasa in town didn't align with the BJP's propagandist narrative. He vehemently denounced the idea of 'soft' or 'hard' Hinduism, asserting that Hinduism stands apart from Hindutva.
Ranbir Kapoor in legal trouble for raising 'Jai Mata Di' slogan during Christmas cake cutting
Directing his criticism towards the BJP, Siddaramaiah pointed out that the Nehruvian era was the foundation of modern India. He questioned the BJP's development initiatives, highlighting that all the dams in the country were constructed during Congress tenures, contrasting with the BJP's lack of contributions in this regard.
Furthermore, he lauded the efforts of past Congress leaders—Nehru, Indira Gandhi, and Rajiv Gandhi—in building the nation, attributing significant developmental milestones, such as digital expansion, to their leadership.
Siddaramaiah discredited the BJP's claims of participating in the freedom struggle against the British, asserting that the Congress was the driving force behind India's independence. He urged people to grasp the distinction between the inclusive nature of Hinduism, embracing diversity, and the exclusionary approach of Hindutva.
Karnataka: MP Ananth Kumar Hegde slams CM Siddaramaiah for using Tippu Sultan’s name in politics
He continued his critique by denouncing the BJP's alleged misinformation, especially regarding developmental achievements like dam construction and digital expansion. He highlighted that social justice in the country owed its existence to the Congress party.
The Chief Minister expressed confidence in Congress's prospects, endorsing Rahul Gandhi's leadership and predicting his rise to Prime Ministership. Siddaramaiah concluded by reiterating that the principles of Hindutva directly oppose the secular values enshrined in the Indian Constitution.

author: CA WILDFIRE BOT
title: Wildfire breaks out in San Joaquin County, CA | Sacramento Bee
text:
Fires
Breaking: Pass Fire reported in San Joaquin County on May 7
The creation of this content included the use of AI based on templates created, reviewed and edited by journalists in the newsroom. Read more on our AI policy here.
First discovered: 2:53 p.m. May 7
Initial location: San Joaquin County, Calif.
Fire type: Wildfire
Fire name: Pass
A new wildfire was reported today at 2:53 p.m. in San Joaquin County.
Pass Fire has been burning on private land. Currently, there is no data on the containment status of the fire and the cause has yet to be determined.
Source: National Interagency Fire Center
This story was originally published May 7, 2025 at 3:22 PM.

author: @LaPresseManche
title: Un grand spectacle équestre va faire voyager le public au haras de Saint-Lô
text:
Épaules en dedans, pas espagnol, cabré, changement de pied rapproché, pirouettes au galop, reprises de dressage de haute école sur musique andalouse … ce premier tableau nous aura présenté l’Espagne et son rapport au cheval pure race , fierté des cavaliers et élégantes Andalouses en costume traditionnel .
Tournois, chutes, combats à l’épée, course à la bague, jeu des anneaux et de la quintaine, toutes ces épreuves seront ensuite annoncées par le héraut d’armes et saluées élégamment par les rubans que les gentes dames jetteront à leur chevalier favori monté sur son fier destrier.
Pour les géographes et historiens Pégase nous aura alors transportés dans l’ère médiévale avant un retour à Saint-Lô (Manche) par l’Amérique des intrépides cavaliers indiens . C’est un grand voyage à travers le monde , et à cheval, qui s’annonce le jeudi 24 juillet 2025 au haras national de Saint-Lô.
Le pôle hippique invite en effet tous les géographes et historiens mais aussi tous les amis des équidés et amateurs de spectacles équestres à venir rencontrer Les cavaliers du monde . Le spectacle commence à 17 heures, dans la cour du haras .
De notre correspondant Gérard HAMEL
Spectacle équestre « Chevaux et cavaliers du monde » ce jeudi 24 juillet à 17 h dans la cour du haras national, à Saint-Lô, 437, rue du Maréchal-Juin. Billetterie sur place à 15 h : 10 € par adulte, 5 € par enfant de 6 à12 ans, gratuit pour les moins de 6 ans.Pour plus d’informations : 02 33 72 47 25, [email protected] , polehippiquestlo.fr Suivez toute l’actualité de vos villes et médias favoris en vous inscrivant à Mon Actu .
#Cheval
